perturbation.original_text: 4.6 This Clause 4 shall survive termination or expiry of this Amendment for a period of five (5) years following such End Date.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.6 This Clause 4 shall survive termination or expiry of this Amendment for a period of one (1) year following such End Date.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period to one year may be deemed unreasonable and inadequate to protect trade secrets or sensitive business information under New York law, especially considering the nature of the maintenance agreement and the information likely exchanged. Under New York law, the determination of a reasonable duration for confidentiality clauses often depends on factors such as the nature of the protected information, the industry standards, and the competitive advantage gained through the confidential information. A one-year period could be challenged as insufficient.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York trade secret law and general contract law principles regarding reasonable duration of confidentiality agreements.

perturbation.changed_text: 5.2.1 Subject to sub-Clause 5.2.5 below and in the event the Representatives (i) fail to create such committee or (ii) do not agree on an amicable settlement within [*****] from the date the committee referred to in this sub-Clause 5.2 has been created or such longer period as may be agreed upon in writing by the Representatives (the "Amicable Settlement Period"), the Dispute shall be exclusively and finally settled under the Rules and Conciliation of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce (the "ICC") by an arbitral tribunal composed of three (3) arbitrators; each Party shall then appoint one (1) arbitrator within **1 day** from the last day of the Amicable Settlement Period and the third arbitrator, who will act as President, will be appointed by the other two (2) arbitrators. In case the two (2) arbitrators appointed by the Parties do not agree on this choice with **1 day** from the date the last arbitrator is appointed, the third arbitrator will be appointed by the ICC Court.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the timeframe to appoint an arbitrator to 1 day is highly unreasonable and impractical, potentially rendering the arbitration clause unenforceable under New York law. New York courts require arbitration agreements to be fair and reasonable. The extremely short timeframe places an undue burden on the parties and could be seen as procedurally unconscionable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York law on arbitration agreements and procedural unconscionability.

perturbation.original_text: Pursuant to and in accordance with Section 5-1401 of the New York General Obligations Law, the Parties hereto agree that this Amendment in all respects, and any claim or cause of action based upon or arising out of this Amendment, or any dealing between the Parties relating to the subject matter of this Amendment or the transactions contemplated hereby or the Company/Repairer relationship being established, shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of the State of New York, U.S.A. as applied to contracts to be performed wholly within the State of New York (Exclusive of Section 7-101 of the New York General Obligations Law which is inapplicable to this Amendment).
perturbation.changed_text: Pursuant to and in accordance with Section 5-1401 of the New York General Obligations Law, the Parties hereto agree that this Amendment in all respects, and any claim or cause of action based upon or arising out of this Amendment, or any dealing between the Parties relating to the subject matter of this Amendment or the transactions contemplated hereby or the Company/Repairer relationship being established, shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of Brazil.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the governing law from New York to Brazil when one of the parties is not based there, and the contract is negotiated and executed in English, creates legal uncertainty and potential conflict. While parties generally have the freedom to choose the governing law, a choice lacking a reasonable relationship to the contract or the parties could be challenged as a violation of public policy or as an attempt to evade mandatory provisions of the law of the jurisdiction with the most significant relationship to the matter. If the contract's performance or significant portions thereof occur in New York, changing the governing law to Brazil could be seen as an attempt to avoid New York's legal protections. New York Courts would very likely refuse to enforce that provision, given that Brazil has very little connection to the subject matter of the agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of conflict of laws and public policy considerations in contract enforcement under New York Law.
